Define the principle of legality in criminal law.;no;"The principle of legality in criminal law is a fundamental concept that ensures individuals can only be held criminally liable for acts that were punishable by law at the time of their commission. This principle is enshrined in Section 1(1) of the Act C of 2012 on the Criminal Code
column2: which states that criminal liability can only be established for an act that was punishable under an Act at the time of commission
column3: except for acts punishable under the generally recognised rules of international law [1].

column2: the principle of legality also applies to acts committed by persons other than Hungarian nationals abroad against a Hungarian national
column3: or a legal person or other legal entity without legal personality established under Hungarian law
column4: which are punishable under Hungarian law [2]. In such cases
column5: the criminal proceedings shall be launched by the Prosecutor General [3].

column3: Section 15 of the same Act lists coercion or threat as one of the reasons for excluding or limiting liability to punishment [4]. Furthermore
column4: Section 19 (1) states that a person shall not be liable to punishment if he commits a punishable act under coercion or threat which prevents him from acting in line with his own will [5].

column1: Discuss the relationship between individual freedom and cooperation with others as per the National Avowal.;yes;"The National Avowal emphasizes the importance of cooperation with others in achieving individual freedom. It states that ""individual freedom can only be complete in cooperation with others"" [1]. This highlights the value placed on collaboration and mutual support in Hungarian society.

The Avowal also recognizes the role of national minorities living in Hungary as part of the Hungarian political community and commits to promoting and safeguarding their languages and cultures [2]. Furthermore
column2: it believes that national culture is a rich contribution to European unity and respects the freedom and culture of other nations [3].

Analyze the state's obligation regarding the protection of national identity and the historic constitution.;yes;"The state's obligation regarding the protection of national identity and the historic constitution is rooted in the Fundamental Law. The state must protect its citizens
column3: and ensure the continuity of the nation's statehood and unity. This is a fundamental obligation of the State
column4: as stated in the Fundamental Law [1]. The state must also protect the Hungarian language and ensure that the child of a Hungarian citizen is a Hungarian citizen by birth.

column1: The historic constitution of Hungary has undergone several amendments that impact national identity protection. The Third Amendment to the Fundamental Law
column2: the Fourth Amendment to the Fundamental Law
column3: the Fifth Amendment to the Fundamental Law
column4: the Sixth Amendment to the Fundamental Law
column5: the Seventh Amendment to the Fundamental Law
column6: the Eighth Amendment to the Fundamental Law
column7: and the Ninth Amendment to the Fundamental Law have all been enacted
column8: as in force on 23 December 2020 [1]. The Fundamental Law of Hungary honours the achievements of the historic constitution and the Holy Crown
column9: which embodies the constitutional continuity of Hungary's statehood and the unity of the nation [2]. It also holds that the protection of the nation's identity rooted in the historic constitution is a fundamental obligation of the State [3].

column1: The state's obligation to protect national identity is influenced by several international agreements and laws. The Fundamental Law of Hungary states that natural resources
column3: and cultural artefacts are the common heritage of the nation
column4: and it is the obligation of the State and everyone to protect and maintain them for future generations [4]. The Act C of 2012 on the Criminal Code emphasizes the protection of fundamental rights
column5: independence
column6: territorial integrity
column8: and national assets of the country
column9: taking into account Hungary's obligations under international and European Union law [5].

column1: If the state fails to protect national identity
column2: it may lead to a loss of trust among citizens
column4: and potentially even the loss of Hungarian citizenship for certain individuals. This could have significant consequences for the state's sovereignty
column5: territorial integrity
column6: and economic stability.

Define the principle of legality in criminal law.;no;"The principle of legality in criminal law is a fundamental concept that ensures individuals can only be held criminally liable for acts that were punishable by law at the time of commission. This principle is enshrined in Section 1(1) of the Act C of 2012 on the Criminal Code
column2: which states that criminal liability can only be established for an act that was punishable under an Act at the time of commission
column3: except for acts punishable under the generally recognised rules of international law [1].

column2: Section 2(2) of the same Act provides that no penalty shall be imposed and no measure shall be applied due to committing a criminal offence if it was not provided for by an Act at the time of commission or
column4: of adjudication [2].

When does the criminal law in force at the time of adjudication apply instead of the law at the time of commission?;no;"The criminal law in force at the time of adjudication applies instead of the law at the time of commission in the following situations:

The new criminal law applies retroactively for adjudicating an act punishable under the generally recognised rules of international law if the act was not punishable under the Hungarian criminal law at the time of commission [1].
A criminal offence shall be adjudicated under the criminal law in force at the time of commission

column3: or is to be adjudged more leniently
column4: the new criminal law shall apply [2].

At what age does criminal liability generally begin?;no;"The criminal liability generally begins at the age of 14 years old. This is based on the Hungarian Criminal Code
column2: which states that a person who commits a criminal offence before reaching the age of 14 shall not be held criminally liable [1]. However

column4: they shall be punished by imprisonment for up to three years if they are between 14 and 18 years old [2].

What are the legal consequences of 'liability for result'?;no;"The legal consequences of 'liability for result' are as follows:

Liability for result as a qualifying circumstance shall only be applied if the perpetrator was at least negligent regarding the result [1]. This is in accordance with Section 9 of the Act C of 2012 on the Criminal Code.
In civil law
column2: liability for hazardous operations is governed by Section 6:535 of the Act V of 2013 on the Civil Code. A person carrying out hazardous activities shall compensate for the resulting damage
column3: unless they can prove that the damage was caused by an unavoidable event outside the scope of the hazardous activity [2].

column1: Furthermore
column2: Section 6:147 of the Act V of 2013 on the Civil Code addresses liability in damages in the event of gratuitous contracts. A person undertaking the performance of a service free of charge shall be required to compensate for the damage caused by their service to the assets of the obligee
column3: unless they can prove that they were not at fault [3].

column1: Additionally
column2: Section 3:59 of the Act V of 2013 on the Civil Code imposes liability on the controlling member of a group of companies in the event of liquidation of a controlled member. The controlling member shall be liable for the claims of creditors not yet satisfied
column3: unless they can prove that the insolvency of the controlled member was not a result of the uniform business policy of the group of companies [4].

column2: Article XXVIII of the Fundamental Law [1] and the Territorial and personal scope section of the Act C of 2012 on the Criminal Code [2] provide some related information.

The conditions for justifiable defence in the Hungarian Criminal Code are not explicitly stated in the provided documents. However
column2: the concept of justifiable defence is generally understood to be a defence that excuses an individual from criminal liability when they have acted in response to a threat or danger.

column1: The Hungarian Criminal Code has several exceptions to justifiable defence. Article XXVIII of the Fundamental Law provides that no one shall be prosecuted or convicted for a criminal offence for which they have already been finally acquitted or convicted in Hungary or another State
column2: as provided for by an Act [6]. This exception applies to extraordinary cases of legal remedy laid down in an Act [7].

column1: Additionally
column2: Article XXVIII states that no one shall be considered guilty until their criminal liability has been established by the final and binding decision of a court [8]. This means that a person cannot be held guilty of a crime until their guilt has been proven in a court of law.

column1: Furthermore
column2: Article XXVIII also provides that persons subject to criminal proceedings shall have the right to defence at all stages of the procedure [9]. Defence counsels shall not be held liable for their opinion expressed while providing legal defence [10].

column1: The Hungarian Criminal Code distinguishes between justifiable defence and self-defence by considering the circumstances of the situation. Justifiable defence is allowed when a person is incapable of self-defence or unable to express their will [11]. This includes cases where the perpetrator consumed drugs before the act
column2: in a manner that can be connected to the commission of the act [11]. Self-defence
column4: is not explicitly defined in the provided documents.

column2: a person shall not be liable to punishment if they commit a punishable act under coercion or threat which prevents them from acting in line with their own will [1]. Additionally
column3: the punishment may be reduced without limitation if the coercion or threat limits the ability of the perpetrator of a criminal offence to act in line with their own will [2].
